intro: Thea bohea var. laxa, commonly known as the Chinese tea plant, is a variant of the Camellia sinensis species native to China. It is characterized by its broad, dark green leaves and is primarily cultivated for its leaves used in tea production. The plant typically grows as an evergreen shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 10 feet. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates with high humidity and well-drained soil. The leaves are harvested several times a year to produce various types of tea, including black and oolong varieties.
